description: The Evidence resource codifies defintions of the evidence variables, the statistical measures and the certainty of those statistics.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The Evidence resource codifies defintions of the evidence variables, the statistical measures and the certainty of those statistics.
element.short: A descriptive and statistical summary of research

element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this evidence is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the evidence is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the evidence to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.
element.short: Canonical identifier for this evidence, represented as a globally unique URI

element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this {{title}} outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this evidence when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.comment: There may be different {{title}} instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the {{title}} with the format [url]|[version].
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the evidence author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the evidence. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the evidence.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.comment: Allows filtering of {{title}}s that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: The status of this evidence. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.isModifierReason: Not known why this is labelled a modifier

element.comment: Allows filtering of {{title}}s that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this evidence is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level evidence.
element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage

element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the {{title}}. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the evidence was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the evidence changes.

element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the {{title}} is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the {{title}}. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the {{title}}. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the evidence.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the evidence.  May also allow for contact.
element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)

element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the {{title}} was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the {{title}} as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the {{title}} is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the {{title}} was created).
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the evidence from a consumer's perspective.
element.short: Natural language description of the evidence

element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate evidence instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.
element.short: The context that the content is intended to support

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.comment: It may be possible for the {{title}} to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the evidence is intended to be used.

element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the {{title}}. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this {{title}}.
element.definition: Explanation of why this evidence is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
A copyright statement relating to the evidence and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the evidence.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the evidence and/or its content.

element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.short: When the evidence was approved by publisher

element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.
element.short: When the evidence was last reviewed

element.comment: The effective period for a {{title}}  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.definition: The period during which the evidence content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the evidence are or are expected to be used instead.
element.short: When the evidence is expected to be used

element.definition: The Population or Subpopulation.
Human-readable summary of the population or subpopulation.
element.short: Description of the population or subpopulation

element.definition: A reference to a Group that defines the population or subpopulation.
element.short: Definition of the population or subpopulation

element.definition: Population Sample Size.
Human-readable summary of population sample size.
Number of studies contributing to this Evidence summary.
Number of participants in the population.
TBD.
TBD.
A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the sample size.
element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes

element.definition: The exposure details. Which could be intervention or comparison/control states.
element.short: Exposure or Intervention or Exposure State

element.definition: Human-readable summary of the exposure state.
A reference to a Group that defines the exposure state (subgroup by exposure within the population).
Sample Size limited to this exposure state.
element.short: Sample Size limited to this exposure state

element.definition: Outcome or Characteristic that is Measured.
element.short: Outcome or Characteristic that is Measured

element.definition: Human-readable summary of sample characteristic or outcome definition.
element.short: Description of sample characteristic or outcome

element.definition: A reference to an EvidenceVariable.
element.short: Definition of the outcome or measured variable

element.definition: Statistic with only 1 variable (non-comparative) to be used for summary statistics of a single variable in a single group.
element.requirements: Must have only 1 measured variable and only 1 group (exposure background and exposure state combination).

element.definition: A human-readable string to describe the findings.

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (eg. summary data meta-analysis).

element.definition: Type of synthesis eg meta-analysis.

binding.description: Types of research studies (types of research methods).

element.definition: Type of study eg randomized trial.
Sample Size for of the univariate statistic.
element.short: Sample Size for of the univariate statistic

element.definition: TBD.

binding.description: Method of reporting variability of estimates, such as confidence intervals, interquartile range or standard deviation.

element.definition: Examples include confidence interval and interquartile range.
Use 95 for a 95% confidence interval.
Lower bound of confidence interval.
Upper bound of confidence interval.

TBD.
TBD.

Footnote or explanatory note about the univariate statistic.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the univariate statistic

element.definition: A description of the certainty of the effect estimate.

binding.description: The quality of the evidence described. The code system used specifies the quality scale used to grade this evidence source while the code specifies the actual quality score (represented as a coded value) associated with the evidence.

element.definition: A rating of the certainty of the effect estimate.
A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the statistic certainty

element.definition: A description of a component of the overall certainty.
element.short: A component that contributes to the overall certainty

binding.description: The subcomponent classification of quality of evidence rating systems.

element.definition: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating.
element.short: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating

binding.description: The quality rating of the subcomponent of a quality of evidence rating.

element.definition: A rating of a subcomponent of rating certainty.
A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the statistic certainty subcomponent

element.definition: Footnote or esplanatory note about the statistic itself.
element.short: Footnote or esplanatory note about the statistic itself

element.definition: Footnote or explanatory note about the measured variable.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the measured variable

element.definition: Covariant statistic(s).
Human-readable summary of sample characteristic.
The first variable of the covariant statistic.
element.short: The first variable of the covariant statistic

element.definition: The second variable of the covariant statistic.
element.short: The second variable of the covariant statistic

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (eg. summary data meta-analysis).

element.definition: Type of synthesis eg meta-analysis.

binding.description: Types of research studies (types of research methods).

element.definition: Type of study eg randomized trial.
Sample size.
Sample size statistic.
A description of the certainty of the effect estimate.
Footnote or explanatory note about the exposure variant covariant statistic.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the exposure variant covariant statistic

element.definition: Footnote or explanatory note about the exposure variant.
element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the exposure variant

Human-readable summary of sample characteristic.

name: Evidence
publisher: Health Level Seven International (Clinical Decision Support)

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated

constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $contained in f:contained return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label
Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The Evidence resource codifies defintions of the evidence variables, the statistical measures and the certainty of those statistics.
element.short: A descriptive and statistical summary of research

element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created

binding.description: A human language.

element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation

element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this evidence is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the evidence is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the evidence to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.
element.short: Canonical identifier for this evidence, represented as a globally unique URI

element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this {{title}} outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this evidence when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.comment: There may be different {{title}} instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the {{title}} with the format [url]|[version].
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the evidence author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the evidence. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the evidence.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.comment: Allows filtering of {{title}}s that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: The status of this evidence. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.isModifierReason: Not known why this is labelled a modifier

element.comment: Allows filtering of {{title}}s that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this evidence is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level evidence.

element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the {{title}}. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the evidence was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the evidence changes.

element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the {{title}} is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the {{title}}. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the {{title}}. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the evidence.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the evidence.  May also allow for contact.
element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)

element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the {{title}} was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the {{title}} as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the {{title}} is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the {{title}} was created).
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the evidence from a consumer's perspective.
element.short: Natural language description of the evidence

element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate evidence instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the evidence is intended to be used.

element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the {{title}}. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this {{title}}.

A copyright statement relating to the evidence and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the evidence.

element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.comment: The effective period for a {{title}}  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Evidence ITUDomainResourceA descriptive and statistical summary of research
+ Warning: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation
Elements defined in Ancestors: id, meta, implicitRules, language, text, contained, extension, modifierExtension
url Σ0..1uriCanonical identifier for this evidence, represented as a globally unique URI
identifier Σ0..*IdentifierAdditional identifier for the evidence
version Σ0..1stringBusiness version of the evidence
name ΣI0..1stringName for this evidence (computer friendly)
title Σ0..1stringName for this evidence (human friendly)
status ?!Σ1..1codedraft | active | retired | unknown
PublicationStatus (Required)
experimental Σ0..1booleanFor testing purposes, not real usage
date Σ0..1dateTimeDate last changed
publisher Σ0..1stringName of the publisher (organization or individual)
contact Σ0..*ContactDetailContact details for the publisher
description 0..1markdownNatural language description of the evidence
useContext Σ0..*UsageContextThe context that the content is intended to support
jurisdiction Σ0..*CodeableConceptIntended jurisdiction for evidence (if applicable)
Jurisdiction (Extensible)
purpose 0..1markdownWhy this evidence is defined
copyright 0..1markdownUse and/or publishing restrictions
approvalDate 0..1dateWhen the evidence was approved by publisher
lastReviewDate 0..1dateWhen the evidence was last reviewed
effectivePeriod Σ0..1PeriodWhen the evidence is expected to be used
exposureBackground 0..*BackboneElementThe Population or Subpopulation
description 0..1stringDescription of the population or subpopulation
population Σ1..1Reference(Group)Definition of the population or subpopulation
populationSampleSize 0..1BackboneElementPopulation Sample Size
description 0..1stringDescription of population sample size
numberOfStudies 0..1integerNumber of contributing studies
numberOfParticipants 0..1integerCumulative number of participants
knownDataCount 0..1integerTBD
numeratorCount 0..1integerTBD
note 0..*AnnotationUsed for footnotes or explanatory notes
exposureVariant 0..*BackboneElementExposure or Intervention or Exposure State
description 0..1stringDescription of the exposure state
groupByExposure Σ1..1Reference(Group)Defintion of the exposure state
exposureSubsetSampleSize 0..1see populationSampleSizeSample Size limited to this exposure state
measuredVariable 0..*BackboneElementOutcome or Characteristic that is Measured
description 0..1stringDescription of sample characteristic or outcome
measuredVariableDefinition Σ1..1Reference(EvidenceVariable)Definition of the outcome or measured variable
univariateStatistic 0..*BackboneElementStatistic with only 1 variable (non-comparative)
description 0..1stringDescription of findings
synthesisType 0..1CodeableConceptType of synthesis
SynthesisType (Extensible)
studyType 0..1CodeableConceptType of study
StudyType (Extensible)
sampleSize 0..1see populationSampleSizeSample Size for of the univariate statistic
statistic 0..*BackboneElementTBD
description 0..1stringTBD
type 0..1CodeableConceptTBD
quantity 0..1QuantityTBD
